Award.AwardTitle: Roads to Achieving a Degree in Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is providing two-year scholarships for a total of 40 students with the goal of increasing the number of graduates with an Associates of Science in Pre-engineering or Physical Science from the University of New Mexico at Gallup (UNM-G). All the students are academically talented students demonstrating financial need and drawn from the surrounding area that is predominantly populated with students from the Navajo Nation and the Zuni Pueblo.

Students are recruited from a variety of sources including local high schools, collaboration with local math and engineering clubs, existing UNM-G "math camps", as well as on-campus learning communities specifically designed for prospective "Roads to Achieving a Degree in Science" (RADS) students. Selection criteria include financial need, academic potential, and achievement. Student support services build on the strong history at UNM-G of educating students who need developmental course work prior to successfully completing their associate degrees and transferring to four year programs. Specific student support activities include specially designed learning communities, faculty advising and recruitment, tutoring, a mentoring program provided by professionals employed in the STEM fields, and development of Summer Bridge programs for RADS Scholars to ease their transition to four year STEM degree programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RADS Outcomes

NSF grant titled ?Roads to Achieve a Degree in Science,? RADS was designed to support students who were pursuing an AS Degree in Science. The award was only for full-time students who attended specifically at The University of New Mexico-Gallup Campus a two-year branch. This allowed students to complete courses so they may advance to a four-year institution.

Fifty-two students were awarded with the RADS scholarship from 2011-2019. Many of these students continued to receive the award with a satisfactory GPA for several semesters. Of course, some students were placed on probation upon agreement by the RADS Committee?s decision. Seven of these scholarship recipients graduated with the AS Degree in Science. An additional two students also graduated with the AS Degree in Science that were not RADS eligible, based on requirements. Thirteen students transferred to a four-year institution such as University of New Mexico-Main in Albuquerque NM, New Mexico State University in Las Cruses New Mexico and New Mexico Tech in Socorro New Mexico. Five of these transferees did complete and graduated with the AS Degree in Science at UNM-G. Two other RADS awarded students did not complete the curriculum but instead transferred to a US Military Branch with satisfactory GPA.  The remaining students were untraceable once departing UNM-Gallup with contact information that had since been changed.

RADS recipients? with satisfactory progress had the opportunity to attend the ?American Indian Science & Engineering Society,? AISES, a nationally recognized conference for STEM careers. This event held in fall semesters annually at different locations in the US. I accompanied students to the following:

2011 AISES National Conference in Minneapolis Minnesota. Theme ?Food for Thought.?

2012 AISES National Conference in Anchorage Alaska. Theme ?Adaptability.?

2013 AISES National Conference in Denver Colorado. Theme ?Elevate.?

2014 AISES National Conference in Orlando Florida. Theme ?Transcend.?

2015 AISES National Conference in Phoenix Arizona. Theme ?Strive-Rise-Thrive.?

2016 AISES National Conference in Minneapolis Minnesota. Theme ?Traditional Knowledge, A better World??

2017 AISES National Conference in Denver Colorado. Theme ?40 Years Supporting Native People in STEM.?

 

Nine of the RADS recipients completed a summer research program at New Mexico State University in Las Cruces New Mexico. The research program was directed by the RADS Co-PI. These students also had the opportunity to present at SACNA, Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native American, Conferences.  Two of these students that presented at SACNAS also presented at the AISES Conference by displaying their research poster.
